stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on implementing the Monty Mole enemies in the 'Mole Hideout' area. The stream focused on solving the physics for the moles' rock-throwing attack, brainstorming and coding a mini-boss encounter, and showcasing a major technical achievement: a completely new, custom collision system for the game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has completely replaced the original Mario 64 collision engine with his own custom system to achieve better stability, a major technical undertaking for the project.
development_findings.quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now. And it's so much more stable.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has a clear philosophy on preserving bugs: he keeps intentional, skill-based exploits like BLJs but removes glitches that can disrupt an average player's experience.
development_findings.quote: If there's a bug in Mario 64 that you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I'll leave it in the game. But if it can happen on accident, I'll remove it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's approach to feedback is to analyze the underlying emotion or problem a player is experiencing, rather than implementing their literal suggestion.
development_findings.quote: When I receive a criticism, I try to figure out what the person was feeling that's wrong... I don't really think about what they're saying as much as I think about what they were feeling.

development_findings.summary: The project is estimated to be 80% complete, with three main courses, two side levels, and a Bowser level remaining.
Kaze engaged in a live, iterative design process for the Monty Mole boss fight, brainstorming, evaluating, and implementing the core logic on stream.
Kaze struggled to solve the physics equation for a projectile's trajectory, first trying ChatGPT unsuccessfully before working through the complex math himself.
development_findings.quote: Look at this shit. Do you really want me to do this on stream? I Don't want to do this on stream.

development_findings.summary: The project is still constrained by the N64's hardware limitations, such as removing collision from a bridge due to RAM limits and dealing with memory bandwidth issues.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes true freedom comes in adulthood with financial independence, contrasting with his dislike for the structured environment of high school.
context_findings.quote: I feel like if you are in school you are simply not a free being like if you want freedom you need like a job and money and stuff and then you can be free.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is on a disciplined diet and fitness regimen, expressing pride and satisfaction in his physical transformation after losing 15 pounds.
context_findings.quote: I'm starting to look fucking chiseled. I didn't know I look this good and now I do.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to launch a Kickstarter for an original 3D platformer game after completing this project, with the goal of hiring other ROM hackers to work with him.

Kaze recounted a negative experience with a sponsor for a bootleg handheld device, where the company was angry with his unconventional ad. This highlights the financial realities and risks of his work as a content creator.
context_findings.quote: The company that's like bootleg devices with 2,000 Nintendo games burned on is gonna sue me yeah right.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes rhythm games because they lack freedom, which he considers a core value in game design. This philosophy influences the kind of games he creates.
context_findings.quote: I value having freedom in games and the rhythm game is the opposite of that it's just an execution test.

key_stories.title: Replacing the Collision Engine
key_stories.summary: Finding the original Mario 64 collision system too unstable, Kaze undertook the massive task of writing a completely new one from scratch. The new system is far more stable, though it unintentionally impacted a classic glitch, showcasing Kaze's commitment to quality even at the cost of major engineering effort.
key_stories.challenge: The original Mario 64 collision system was deemed 'unusable' and unstable, causing players to get stuck in complex level geometry.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided to scrap the original game's code entirely and engineer a new collision system from the ground up. He demonstrated its success by navigating Mario through geometrically complex areas that would have broken the original engine.
key_stories.outcome: The game now features a more robust, custom-built collision system that prevents players from getting stuck. An unintended side effect was making the BLJ glitch more difficult, which Kaze considers a downside.
key_stories.key_quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now. And it's so much more stable.

key_stories.title: Solving the Rock Throw Physics
key_stories.summary: To make an enemy's projectile attack work, Kaze had to solve a complex physics problem. After a failed attempt to use AI for a shortcut, he demonstrated his persistence by working through the difficult math himself on stream, eventually finding the solution through trial and error.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to implement the physics for Monty Moles throwing rocks to accurately hit Mario's current position, which required a complex trajectory calculation.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to get a formula from ChatGPT, which failed. He then reluctantly worked through the physics derivation himself live on stream, encountering errors before finally identifying the correct components of the equation and implementing it in the code.
key_stories.outcome: After solving the math, Kaze successfully implemented the behavior, allowing the moles to accurately target and throw rocks at Mario, forming the basis of their attack pattern and the area's boss fight.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at this shit. Do you really want me to do this on stream? I Don't want to do this on stream.

key_stories.title: Brainstorming the Mole Boss Fight
key_stories.summary: Faced with an empty boss arena, Kaze used the stream as a live brainstorming session to design the encounter. By iterating through several ideas with his community, he landed on a dynamic Whac-A-Mole concept that fit the level's theme and enemy mechanics.
key_stories.challenge: An arena in the Mole Hideout was built for a boss fight, but the specific mechanics of the fight had not been designed yet.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed ideas live on stream with his chat. He considered and discarded several concepts, including a simple 'defeat all enemies' room and a power-up-based fight, before settling on the more dynamic random-hole concept.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided on a final design: a Whac-A-Mole style encounter where five moles pop out of random holes, with the fight escalating in speed as moles are defeated. He then began implementing the logic for this design.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we may need a better idea for the boss fight. I kind of made this area before even thinking about it.
